quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Week 3 of your 12-week project. Sponsor asks: 'Can you add mobile app version alongside the web app? Same deadline, same budget.' Your team says they need 200 extra hours. Current team velocity: 20 hours/week, 60 total hours available in remaining 9 weeks. What do you tell the sponsor?
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's the CORRECT response?

options.A: Yes, let's add mobile‚Äîour team is efficient
options.B: No‚Äîthe new scope (200 hrs) exceeds available capacity (60 hrs), so either budget, schedule, or scope must change
options.C: Yes, but extend the deadline by 10 weeks for the mobile version
options.D: Let the team decide if they can handle it

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Scope, schedule, and budget are linked by constraints

insights.explanation: You cannot change scope without affecting schedule or budget (or both). Adding mobile without changing timeline or budget is impossible with the given capacity.
insights.pmbokSupport: Project constraints (scope, time, cost) are interdependent. Change one, something else changes

insights.explanation: 200 hours of work vs. 60 hours available = gap. This isn't negotiable‚Äîit's math. You need to close this gap explicitly.
insights.pmbokSupport: Resource planning ensures capacity exists before committing to scope

insights.explanation: Adding work without adjusting constraints is the #1 reason projects fail. Saying 'yes' to scope changes without data enables failure.
insights.pmbokSupport: Manage scope baselines and control scope changes through formal processes

trapSection.explanation: Scope decisions require understanding the constraint impact, not hope.

trapTable.violation: Ignores the math: 200 hours of work doesn't fit in 60 hours of capacity
Changes scope without discussing this trade-off with sponsor
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Assuming sponsor will accept deadline change

trapTable.violation: Scope decisions are PM + sponsor decisions, not team decisions

checklist: Is there a gap? If yes, which constraint will change?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Scope + schedule + budget are locked together. New scope requires trade-off. Calculate before saying yes or no.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Scope management controls what's in and what's out of the project:

rows.action: Define what's IN the project clearly. What will be delivered? What will NOT be delivered?
Break project into work packages. Hierarchical decomposition. Ensures nothing is missed or duplicated.
keyQuestions: How do we organize the work?

rows.action: Define how you'll know the deliverable is done. Specific, measurable, testable criteria.
rows.examKeywords: Acceptance criteria, Definition of done, Validation

rows.action: Establish a scope baseline. Document scope in project charter, requirements docs. Create change control gates.
rows.examKeywords: Scope baseline, Approved scope, Change control

rows.action: When someone asks to change scope, evaluate impact: cost, schedule, risk. Then decide yes/no/defer.
rows.examKeywords: Change request, Impact analysis, Approval authority

pmbokConnection.quote: Scope management controls what's included and excluded from the project

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: In-scope = included in project | Out-of-scope = excluded | Scope creep = uncontrolled addition | Scope baseline = approved scope document | Change control = formal process for scope changes
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: Say 'yes' to scope changes only after evaluating impact and securing approvals. Say 'no' to changes that exceed available capacity.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'scope,' 'change request,' 'in-scope,' 'out-of-scope' ‚Üí Identify baseline scope. Calculate impact. Apply change control process.

secondScenario.title: üéØ Apply S.C.O.P.E.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your approved scope: web app, 3 user roles, basic reporting. Mid-project, sponsor asks: 'Can we add advanced analytics? Just 3 extra features.' No timeline/budget change mentioned. This will require 150 development hours. Team capacity: 20 hours/week, 8 weeks remaining. How do you respond?
secondScenario.question: What's your approach?

options.A: No‚Äîthis exceeds capacity and isn't in scope
options.C: Submit a change request documenting scope change, impact (150 hrs, schedule slip of ~7 weeks, or budget increase), and get sponsor decision
options.D: Ask the team if they can 'squeeze it in'

quotes.text: Scope creep is the silent project killer. One small feature doesn't seem bad. Ten small features? That's a different project and no one noticed the switch.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Scope baseline is the approved project scope plus approved changes. Control scope by managing changes through formal processes.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: Scope Controls Schedule & Budget
fieldInsights.insight: Your sponsor wants deadline and budget fixed. The only variable is scope. Protect the baseline. Every 'yes' to new features either breaks deadline or budget.

fieldInsights.title: Change Control is Your Boundary
fieldInsights.insight: Formal change control isn't bureaucracy‚Äîit's the mechanism that says 'your request matters, let's discuss the trade-off.' Without it, chaos.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The Mountain's Summit Boundaries

story.title: Defining the Expedition Scope
story.narrative: A mountain expedition has a defined scope. Adding activities at the last minute risks the main objective...

scenes.description: Scope: Reach summit of Peak A. In-scope: Base Camp setup, 4 intermediate camps, summit push. Out-of-scope: Climbing Peak B (different mountain), extended research stays.
WBS: Logistics (permits, equipment) ‚Üí Acclimatization ‚Üí Camp 1 ‚Üí Camp 2 ‚Üí Camp 3 ‚Üí Summit push. Each level is understood.
How do we know success? Summit flag planted, all climbers safely returned, within 14-day window. Clear definition of 'done.'
Approved scope: 12 climbers, 10,000 lbs supplies, 14-day timeline. This is the baseline. Only formal change control can modify it.
Week 2: Sponsor asks 'Can we add side research on glaciers (5 extra days)?' Evaluate impact: Extends timeline to 19 days (food shortage), or reduce summit push time (risk). Decide with data.

story.moral: Scope management is like expedition planning: **S**tate the objective, **C**reate work breakdown, **O**btain acceptance criteria, **P**lan baselines, **E**valuate all changes against constraints.
